analytic.title: PARTIAL ACTIONS OF GROUPS

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Inverse semigroups; group actions AMS Subject Classification (2000): 20M18

div.p: A partial action of a group G on a set X is a weakening of the usual notion of a group action: the function G × X → X that defines a group action is replaced by a partial function; in addition, the existence of g • (h • x) implies the existence of (gh) • x, but not necessarily conversely. Such partial actions are extremely widespread in mathematics, and the main aim of this paper is to prove two basic results concerning them. First, we obtain an explicit description of Exel's universal inverse semigroup S(G), which has the property that partial actions of the group G give rise to actions of the inverse semigroup S(G). We apply this result to the theory of graph immersions. Second, we prove that each partial group action is the restriction of a universal global group action. We describe some applications of this result to group theory and the theory of E-unitary inverse semigroups.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Partial group actions arise by weakening the usual definition of a group action. To define what they are, let G be a group and X a set. A partial function from G × X to X is denoted by (g, x) → g • x, and we write ∃g • x to mean that g • x is defined. We say that (g, x) → g • x defines a partial action of G on X if the following two conditions hold: (PA1) ∃g • x implies that ∃g -1 • (g • x), and g -1 • (g • x) = x. (PA2) ∃g • (h • x) implies that ∃(gh) • x and g • (h • x) = (gh) • x.
We say that the partial action is unital if the following condition also holds: (PA3) ∃1 • x for every x ∈ X, and 1 • x = x. a

The essential difference between partial group actions and the usual "global" group actions lies in condition (PA2): from the existence of g • (h • x) we can infer the existence of (gh) • x, but not conversely. b This condition also distinguishes partial group actions amongst the local transformation groups of differential geometry [25] of which they form a special class; for arbitrary local transformation groups, the existence of g • (h • x) does not imply the existence of (gh) • x.

The term "partial action of a group" was introduced by Exel [5], who incorporated axiom (PA3) in his definition, whereas Coulbois [4] uses the term "pre-action" for a special class of unital partial actions. We have adopted Exel's terminology because the relationship between partial actions and actions parallels the relationship between partial bijections and bijections.

The reader will recall that an action of a group G on a set X can also be defined by means of a homomorphism from G to the symmetric group on X. We can similarly reformulate partial group actions in terms of appropriate morphisms. To do this, we need the notion of a "premorphism" introduced in 1977 by McAlister and Reilly [20]. First recall that on an inverse semigroup S we can define a partial order by a ≤ b if and only if a = be for some idempotent e. That this is a partial order is a standard result proved in any of the semigroup references. It is called the natural partial order and, whenever we use a partial order on an inverse semigroup, it will always be this one. A function θ: S → T between inverse semigroups is said to be a premorphism c if the following two axioms hold: (PM1) θ(s -1 ) = θ(s) -1 for all s ∈ S. (PM2) θ(s)θ(t) ≤ θ(st) for all s, t ∈ S.
If S and T are both monoids then the premorphism is said to be unital if the following axiom also holds:

The theory of premorphisms was subsequently developed in [26], [27], where they were called "prehomomorphisms". It is evident that a partial action of a group G on a set X is nothing other than a premorphism from G to the inverse semigroup I(X), the symmetric inverse monoid on X. The partial action is unital precisely when the corresponding premorphism is unital.

Partial group actions are extremely widespread in mathematics. One of the first examples arises in the theory of Möbius transformations: the Möbius group acts globally on the Riemann sphere but only partially on the complex plane. More generally, if G is any group which acts globally on the set X, and Y is any subset of X, then it is easy to check that G acts partially on Y . We say that the partial action arises by restricting the global action. In the case of Möbius transformations, one starts with the partial action and proves that it is the restriction of a global action. We say that the action arises from the partial action by globalization. In addition, partial group actions play a role in: C * -algebras [5,24]; the Ribes-Zalesskiȋ property of groups [4]; model theory [9,7]; tilings [15]; R-trees [28,6]; and group presentations [18]. We shall discuss some of these examples in more detail at the appropriate places in the paper.

Since the first draft of this paper was distributed, Benjamin Steinberg has developed some of the ideas in this paper much further [30]. He characterises when a partial action on a connected complex has a connected globalization and when it has a globalization which is a tree.
We prove two basic results on partial group actions.

Result 1. In Sec. 2, our main result, Theorem 2.4, was motivated by Exel's paper [5]. Exel proves (his Theorem 4.2) that there is an inverse semigroup S(G) with the property that there is a one-to-one correspondence between unital partial actions of G on X and actions of S(G) on X. Exel constructs S(G) by means of generators and relations. Although he obtains a lot of information about the structure of S(G), his work falls slightly short of an explicit description. We rectify this by showing that S(G) is the Birget-Rhodes expansion of the group G (see [2,3]) using Szendrei's description of this semigroup in [31]. We apply Theorem 2.4 to the theory of graph immersions partially motivated by some ideas to be found in [28].

Result 2. Whereas in Sec. 2, we kept the set X fixed and replaced the group G by an inverse monoid constructed from G, in Sec. 3, we keep the group G fixed and replace the set X by a larger set X which contains X and on which G acts globally.

In our second main result, Theorem 3.4, we prove that every partial group action can be globalized in a universal way. The construction which underpins our result has been rediscovered a number of times and we make no claim to novelty in that; the novelty, such as it is, lies in our proof of the role of this construction within the theory of partial actions of groups. The construction has appeared in a surprisingly wide variety of areas which suggests to us that partial actions of groups are of some interest. Here are a few examples.
• It is the basis of Poincaré's theorem for constructing Fuchsian groups [1].
• It is the basis of Macbeath's theorem on group presentations [18].
• It is the basis of Munn's proof of the P -theorem [23].

• It is the basis of Megrelishvili's work on embedding topological spaces into spaces with strong properties of homogeneity [21]. • It was used by Hrushovski [9] as a tool in establishing the small index property for certain structures in model theory.
• In [6], the authors mention that Rips uses the construction in studying groups acting on R-trees.

We describe applications of the globalization theorem to continuous partial actions in Sec. 3.2 and to partial actions on posets in Sec. 3.3; this latter makes the connection with Munn's work mentioned above. Throughout this paper, we shall use basic results from inverse semigroup theory; see Howie [8], Lawson [17] or Petrich [27].

div.p: In Sec. 2.1, we show how to construct an action of an inverse monoid from a partial action of a group, completing the work of Exel [5]. We describe an application of this result to the theory of graph immersions in Sec. 2.2.

div.p: In Sec. 3.1, we prove that every partial group action arises by restricting a global group action. In Secs. 3.2 and 3.3, we study structured versions of this result for topological spaces and posets respectively.

In topology, Megrelishvili [21] uses the globalization construction to prove some results on embedding topological spaces into spaces having certain homogeneity properties, whereas in [22], he discusses analogues of this work in other categories. div.head: The P -theorem
div.p: Let G be a group acting globally on the set X, and let Y ⊆ X such that G • Y = X. Then G acts partially on the set Y and by Proposition 3.5, the globalization of this partial action is isomorphic to the action of G on X. Thus the pair (G, X) is a globalization of the partial action determined by the pair (G, Y ). This situation is reminiscent of one of the basic constructions of inverse semigroup theory, which we now recall.

A McAlister triple (G, X, Y ) consists of a group G, a partially ordered set X, a subsemilattice and order ideal Y of X, together with an action of G on X by order automorphisms such that G•Y = X, and for every g ∈ G we have that g •Y ∩Y = ∅; this last condition is equivalent to the statement that the premorphism θ from G to I(Y ) induced by the partial action of G on Y has the property that θ(g) is always non-empty. Such triples are used to construct E-unitary semigroups. In this section, we explain the exact connection between globalizations of partial actions of groups and the theory of E-unitary inverse semigroups. As a consequence, we shed light on Munn's proof of the P -theorem [23]. To do this, we shall need to consider a special class of partial actions of groups: namely, partial actions of groups on semilattices, together with their globalizations. We begin by making precise the definition of such actions.

Let Y be a meet semilattice, and let I(Y ) denote the inverse monoid consisting of order isomorphisms between non-empty order ideals of Y . Observe that the intersection of two non-empty order ideals of Y is again non-empty because Y is a meet semilattice. A unital premorphism from a group G to I(Y ) will be said to define a unital partial action of the group G on the semilattice Y .

The McAlister triple constructed in Theorem 3.19 is nothing other than the McAlister triple of the E-unitary inverse semigroup associated with the partial action by means of Construction 1 in the proof of Theorem 3.17. The sequence which begins with an E-unitary inverse semigroup, applies Construction 2 of Theorem 3.17, and then proves Lemma 3.18 and Theorem 3.19 is identical to the proof of the P -theorem to be found in Munn's paper [23]. At the set-theoretic level, therefore, Munn was essentially proving the globalization theorem for a group acting partially on the set Y .

In globalizing the partial action on a semilattice, we are in general only able to construct a partially ordered set. We can determine when the globalization is also a semilattice by using inverse semigroup theory. An E-unitary inverse semigroup is constructed from a McAlister triple (G, X, Y ) in which X is a semilattice precisely when the semigroup is of a type known as F-inverse (see [17,Sec. 7.4] for more information and references). We may therefore deduce the following result from Theorem 3.19. Theorem 3.20. Let θ: G → I(Y ) be a unital partial action of the group G on the semilattice Y . Then the universal globalization of θ is a semilattice if and only if the E-unitary inverse semigroup constructed from θ is F -inverse.
